sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a solenoid
message_1: A physics student needs to calculate the magnetic field B at the center of a solenoid which has 200 turns, a length of 50 cm and a radius of 2 cm. The current passing through the solenoid is 5 A. Calculate the magnetic field B in tesla at the center of the solenoid.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field B at the center of a solenoid, we can use the formula:

B = μ₀ * n * I

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A), n is the number of turns per unit length (turns/meter), and I is the current passing through the solenoid (in amperes).

First, we need to find the number of turns per unit length (n). Since the solenoid has 200 turns and a length of 50 cm (0.5 meters), we can calculate n as follows:

n = turns / length
n = 200 / 0.5
n = 400 turns/meter

Now, we can plug in the values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A) * 400 turns/m * 5 A

B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A) * 2000 turns*m⁻¹*A
B ≈ (12.57 × 10⁻⁷ T) * 2000
B ≈ 25.14 × 10⁻⁴ T

So, the magnetic field B at the center of the solenoid is approximately 2.514 × 10⁻³ T or 2.514 mT (millitesla).
